questions.text: Thrombocytopenia, eczema and recurrent infections are seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome
Explanation: Thrombocytopenia, eczema and recurrent infections are seen in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.

Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome

  • X-linked recessive
  • Caused by mutations in the gene located at Xp11.23 that encodes Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP)
  • Pathology:
    • Mutations in the WASP gene affect T lymphocytes and other lymphocyte subsets, i.e. dendritic cells, and platelets
    • WASp regulates the actin cytoskeleton and thus plays an important role in many lymphocyte functions, including cell adhesion and migration and the formation of synapses between antigen-presenting and target cell.s
    • Clinical Triad: Immunodeficiency, thrombocytopenia, and eczema.
  • Clinical manifestation:
    • Recurrent bacterial infections
    • Eczema
    • Bleeding
    • Associated with IBD - Colitis
    • Increased risk of development of malignant lymphoma
  • Investigation:
    • IgM levels in the serum are low, but levels of IgG are usually normal. Paradoxically the levels of IgA and IgE are often elevated
    • Blood smear: Thrombocytopenia, reduced-sized platelets, impaired platelet aggregation.
    • Diagnosis is made by expression of intracellular immunofluorescence analysis of WAS protein (WASp) in blood cells. There is defective or absent WAS protein.
  • Treatment:
    • Prophylactic antibiotics
    • Immunoglobulin G (IgG) supplementation
    • Topical treatment of eczema

 

Chediak-Higashi syndrome (Option B) (CHS) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by recurrent pyogenic infections, partial oculocutaneous albinism, neurologic abnormalities, and thrombocytopenia. However, eczema is not a feature of CHS.

Thrombocytopenia-absent radius syndrome (Option B) (TAR syndrome) is characterized by severe thrombocytopenia at birth and the absence of the radius bone in the forearm, with thumbs typically present. Eczema is not part of the presentation in TAR syndrome.

Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome (Option D) involves oculocutaneous albinism, platelet dysfunction causing bleeding, pulmonary fibrosis, and granulomatous colitis. While thrombocytopenia and recurrent infections may occur, eczema is not a characteristic of this syndrome.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a 50-year-old man who presents with symptoms of anemia, fever, and recurrent nosebleeds? The patient has hepatosplenomegaly and lab investigations indicate a hemoglobin level of 6g/dL, a total leukocyte count of 40,000/cu.mm with 10% blasts, and a platelet count of 12,000/cu.mm. Further investigation reveals the presence of t(8;21) in the blasts.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Acute myeloblastic leukemia

Explanation:

  • The diagnosis for this patient is Acute myeloblastic leukemia (AML) as it has clinical and laboratory features consistent with AML and chromosomal translocation of t(8;21).
  • AML is the most common type of acute leukaemia in adults and is typically seen in the elderly. When symptomatic, clinical features are those of pancytopenia. The diagnosis is clinched by bone marrow showing >20% myeloblasts. Emergencies include hyperleukocytosis, neurologic involvement, and DIC.


Aetiology of AML:

  1. Idiopathic
  • 25-50% cases
  1. Bone Marrow Failure
  • Fanconi Anemia
  • Diamond-Blackfan Syndrome Diamond-Blackfan Anemia (DBA) is a rare inherited form of macrocytic anemia characterised by a failure of erythropoiesis in the bone marrow.
  • Shwachman-Diamond Syndrome: An autosomal recessive disorder involving exocrine pancreatic insufficiency.
  1. Defective DNA Repair
  • Bloom Syndrome
  • Ataxia Telangiectasia
  1. Down Syndrome
  • AML is associated with Down syndrome, particularly the subtype known as Acute Megakaryoblastic Leukemia (AML M7), which involves the GATA1 gene.
  1. Exposure to Anticancer Drugs

 
  • Alkylating agents -> Monosomy 5 & 7 -> AML (After 4-6 years).
  • Anticancer drugs (Topoisomerase 2 inhibitors) -> Chromosome 11 involvement -> AML (After 1-3 years).
  1. Radiation Exposure

Exposure to radiation, benzene, phenylbutazone, and chloramphenicol may increase the risk of developing AML and bone marrow failure.
  1. t(15:17)

 

Chromosomal translocation results in the PML-RARA fusion gene, which is associated with acute promyelocytic leukaemia (APL), a subtype of AML.
  1. t(8:21)

Chromosomal translocation (RUNX1- RUNX1T1) is associated with myeloid sarcoma.
  1. Inversion 16 or t(16;16).

-

Work up of AML:

  • Blast concentration <20% in peripheral blood/bone marrow aspiration.
  • Decreased Hb
  • Decreased platelet count
  • Decreased TLC initially

 

ALL (Option A) is the most common childhood leukaemia having symptoms such as fever, night sweats, unexplained weight loss painless lymphadenopathy bone pain which are not present here.

Pre-leukaemia (Option C) Is a myelodysplastic syndrome

Aleukemic leukaemia (Option D) Is a rare type of leukaemia in which the leucocyte count is normal or to the lower side.

questions.text: What is the interpretation of elevated serum Calcium levels in a patient with normal serum alkaline phosphatase, PTH, and Vitamin D3 levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Multiple myeloma

Explanation:

  • Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell disorder characterized by the excessive production of monoclonal immunoglobulins (M-protein). In multiple myeloma, serum calcium levels can be elevated while SAP, PTH, and vitamin D3 levels remain normal. This occurs due to osteolytic lesions and release of calcium from damaged bone tissue due to increased osteoclast activity stimulated by cytokines produced by malignant plasma cells.
  • The normal SAP levels in multiple myeloma help distinguish it from other bone disorders, as SAP is typically elevated in conditions with increased osteoblastic activity. In multiple myeloma, the predominant process is osteolytic rather than osteoblastic, hence SAP remains normal despite bone involvement.

Diagnostic Criteria for Multiple Myeloma

  • Presence of clonal bone marrow plasma cells or biopsy-proven bony/extramedullary plasmacytoma and anyone or more of the following myeloma-defining events:
  • Evidence of one or more indicators of end-organ damage attributed to the plasma cell disorder, specifically: (CRAB)
    • Hypercalcemia: Serum calcium >0.25 mmol/L above the upper limit of normal or >2.75 mmol/L (>11 mg/dL). PTH levels, Vit-D levels are normal
    • Renal Insufficiency: Creatinine clearance <40 mL/min or serum creatinine >177 μmol/L (>2 mg/dL).
    • Anemia: Hemoglobin >20 g/L below the lower limit of normal or haemoglobin <100 g/L or <10g/100ml.
    • Bone Lesions: One or more osteolytic lesions identified on skeletal radiography, CT, or PET-CT.

Biomarkers of Malignancy (any one of the following):

  • Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥60%.
  • Involved: uninvolved serum-free light chain ratio ≥100.
  • 1 focal lesion on MRI studies.

Serum markers: Hypercalcemia, ↑ β2 microglobulin

 

Vitamin D intoxication (Option A): In vitamin D intoxication, both serum calcium and vitamin D3 levels are typically elevated. Additionally, PTH levels are usually suppressed due to the negative feedback mechanism between vitamin D and PTH. Since vitamin D3 levels are normal in this case, vitamin D intoxication can be ruled out.

Hyperparathyroidism (Option B): Hyperparathyroidism is characterized by increased PTH levels, which stimulate the release of calcium from bone, resulting in elevated serum calcium levels. In this case, since PTH levels are normal, hyperparathyroidism is not the likely diagnosis.

Nutritional rickets (Option D): This option is incorrect as nutritional rickets is a condition caused by a deficiency of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. In rickets, serum calcium levels would typically be decreased rather than elevated. Additionally, vitamin D levels would be low, which is not the case here.

questions.text: Which of the following interfere with iron absorption?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Phytates

Explanation:

  • Phytates are naturally occurring compounds found in certain plant foods such as whole grains, legumes, and nuts. These compounds have the ability to bind to iron and form insoluble complexes in the digestive tract, significantly reducing iron absorption and bioavailability.

Factors Increasing Iron Absorption

Factors Decreasing Iron Absorption
  • Acidic stomach environment
  • Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) (Option A Ruled Out)
  • Empty stomach
  • Meat proteins
  • Citric acid
  • Haem iron sources (meat, fish)
  • Fermented foods
  • Iron deficiency state
  • Reduced stomach acid
  • Proton pump inhibitors
  • Antacids
  • Tetracycline (chelates iron)
  • Phytates (Option B) (in cereals, legumes)
  • Tea and coffee (tannins)
  • Calcium-rich foods
  • High fiber meals

 

Vitamin C (Option A): Vitamin C, also known as ascorbic acid, enhances iron absorption rather than interfering with it. It helps in the conversion of non-heme iron (the form of iron found in plant-based foods) to a more absorbable form.

Oxalate (Option C): Oxalate, found in certain foods like spinach, rhubarb, and beet greens, can affect calcium absorption, but it does not affect iron absorption. While oxalates can bind to minerals, their primary impact is on calcium rather than iron metabolism.

Myoglobin (Option D): Myoglobin is a protein found in muscle tissue that stores oxygen and is found in food such as meat. While myoglobin does contain iron, it is not involved in the absorption of iron from the diet.

questions.text:
An elderly woman presented with symptoms of confusion, thirst, and abdominal pain. On examination, she had pallor and thoracic spine tenderness. X-ray spine showed osteolytic lesions. Her lab investigations showed the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?


	Hb - 6.9g/dl
	WBC 4000/cm3 with normal differential count
	Serum calcium 13mg/dl
	Creatinine 2.3mg/dl
	Total protein 9g/dl
	Albumin 2.4g/dl
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Multiple myeloma

  • The clinical scenario of an elderly woman with confusion, thirst, and abdominal pain, along with hypercalcemia, renal failure (elevated creatinine), anemia, osteolytic lesions (CRAB features), hypoalbuminemia, and elevated total proteins, points towards the diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

Multiple Myeloma (MM):

  • Malignant disorder characterized by proliferation of a single clone of plasma cells derived from β-cells in the bone marrow.
  • It is the second most common adult hematological malignancy.
  • Most common cancer with skeletal components as its primary site.

Investigations of Multiple myeloma:

  • Hematological Analysis:
    • It may reveal anemia; ESR is usually elevated.
    • Rare cases of plasma cell leukemia with high plasma cell counts >2000 plasma cells/μL.
    • Serum calcium and urea nitrogen may be elevated.
    • Serum alkaline phosphatase is usually normal.
    • Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation
  • A/G ratio: Decreased
    • Increased level of β2 microglobulin.
    • Decreased albumin
  • Renal function test: Increased serum creatinine and uric acid.
  • Imaging:
    • Chest and bone radiographs: Lytic lesions/diffuse osteopenia
    • MRI: Extent of bone marrow infiltration and cord or root compression in patients with pain syndrome
    • PET/CT: Assess bone damage, extramedullary sites of the disease
  • Anion gap: (Na+ + K+) – (Cl- + HCO3-): Decreased
  • Serum or urine electrophoresis: M spike
  • Serum light chain assay: Increased
  • Immunofixation: Detects subtypes of light chain.
  • 24-hour urine specimen: Bence Jones protein (serum-free light chains) excretion
  • Fat pad biopsy: To detect amyloid deposits
  • Flow cytometry: CD 138+ (bone marrow plasma cells)
  • FISH:
    • Done to detect chromosomal abnormalities
    • Chromosome 17 deletion and translocation leads to poor prognosis.
  • Bone marrow biopsy: Plasmacytosis >10%

Clinicopathologic diagnosis of multiple myeloma is based on the following:

  • Clonal plasma cells in bone marrow
  • Presence of CRAB criteria (hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, anemia and bone lesions)

Metastatic breast cancer (Option A): While metastatic breast cancer can involve bones and cause hypercalcemia, the presence of monoclonal gammopathy (elevated total protein) and anemia strongly favors multiple myeloma.

Primary hyperparathyroidism (Option C) is typically characterized by hypercalcemia and low phosphorus but does not cause anemia, monoclonal gammopathy, hypoalbuminemia, or osteolytic bone lesions.

Milk-alkali syndrome (Option D) arises from excessive intake of calcium and alkali (often in the form of calcium supplements or vitamin D). It results in hypercalcemia, alkalosis, nephrocalcinosis, and nephrolithiasis, none of which are evident in this patient.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old male patient with heart failure is scheduled for a heart transplant. His renal function test is deranged, and haemoglobin is 6gm%. The physician ordered 2 units of whole blood. Four hours after transfusion, he developed severe respiratory distress. On examination, he is hypoxemic, has tachycardia and his mean arterial pressure is elevated. Which of the following are the best investigations for the above scenario?


	Chest X-ray
	Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) level
	Absolute neutrophil count
	Leucocyte antibodies
	Platelets
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - 1 and 2

  • The clinical scenario of an elderly patient with heart failure, deranged renal function, and developing respiratory distress with hypoxia, tachycardia, and elevated mean arterial pressure following a blood transfusion points towards a diagnosis of transfusion- associated circulatory overload (TACO). The best investigations in the case of TACO are chest X-ray and BNP levels.

Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO):

Features

  • Occur after transfusion of red blood cells or plasma products in 1% to 8.9% of transfusions.
  • Has become the leading cause of transfusion-related deaths

Causes/Risk Factors

  • Older age
  • Renal failure
  • Preexisting fluid overload
  • Cardiac dysfunction
  • Administration of a large volume of blood components
  • Excessive transfusion rate beyond the patient's hemodynamic tolerance.

Diagnosis

  • Hypoxia, dyspnea
  • Tachycardia
  • Systolic hypertension
  • Left heart failure
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Increased central venous pressure
  • Elevated brain natriuretic peptide (BNP)
  • Chest X-ray: Bilateral alveolar infiltrates

Prevention

  • Identify at-risk patients.
  • Close monitoring and slow transfusion rates, 1 RBC concentrate over 3-4 hours.
  • Diuretics for hemodynamically stable patients with a history of TACO.

Treatment

  • Stopping the transfusion
  • Administering oxygen
  • Diuretics

Absolute neutrophil count (Option 3) (ANC) measures the number of neutrophils and is used to assess infection or inflammation. However, TACO is a condition caused by fluid overload and not by infection or inflammation, so ANC is not relevant in this case.

Leucocyte antibodies (Option 4) are typically used to identify immune reactions related to transfusions, such as Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI) or febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions, which are not the primary concern in TACO.

Platelets (Option 5): While platelet levels are useful for assessing bleeding or platelet-related disorders, they are not directly relevant in the diagnosis of TACO.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman was brought to the emergency department with symptoms of breathlessness anemia and severe bone pain. On evaluation a hemoglobin level was found to be 5.4 g/dl, urea level of 86 mg/dl, creatinine level of 6 mg/dl, calcium level of 12, and potassium level of 4.4 and the bone marrow aspiration revealed over 60% of plasma cells. Which of the following could be the appropriate next course of action for the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Dexamethasone + fluids

Explanation:

  • Clinical and laboratory features of CRAB (hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, anemia, and bone lesions) and >10% clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow, point towards the diagnosis of Multiple myeloma. The next line of management for this typically involves initiating treatment with a combination of dexamethasone (corticosteroid) and fluids.

Investigations of Multiple myeloma:

  • Hematological Analysis:
    • It may reveal anemia; ESR is usually elevated.
    • Rare cases of plasma cell leukemia with high plasma cell counts >2000 plasma cells/μL.
    • Serum calcium and urea may be elevated.
    • Serum alkaline phosphatase is usually normal.
    • Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation
  • A/G ratio: Decreased
    • Increased level of β2 microglobulin.
    • Decreased albumin
  • Renal function test: Increased serum creatinine and uric acid.
  • Imaging:
    • Chest and bone radiographs: Lytic lesions/diffuse osteopenia
    • MRI: Extent of bone marrow infiltration and cord or root compression in patients with pain syndrome
    • PET/CT: Assess bone damage, extramedullary sites of the disease
  • Anion gap: (Na+ + K+) – (Cl- + HCO3-): Decreased
  • Serum or urine electrophoresis: M spike
  • Serum light chain assay: Increased
  • Immunofixation: Detects subtypes of light chain.
  • 24-hour urine specimen: Bence Jones protein (serum-free light chains) excretion
  • Fat pad biopsy: To detect amyloid deposits
  • Flow cytometry: CD 138+ (bone marrow plasma cells)
  • FISH:
    • Done to detect chromosomal abnormalities
    • Chromosome 17 deletion and translocation leads to poor prognosis.
  • Bone marrow biopsy: Plasmacytosis >10%

Treatment of Multiple Myeloma:

  • Induction Phase: Drugs used:
    • Steroids: Dexamethasone/Prednisolone
    • Immunomodulatory agents: Thalidomide/Lenalidomide
    • Proteasome inhibitors: Bortezomib/Carfilzomib
    • Targeted antibodies: Daratumumab (CD 38 Ab)
  • Autologous Stem Cell Transplantation: Involves removal, storage, and reinfusion of the patient’s own stem cells after high-dose myeloablative therapy.

 

Prognosis of Multiple Myeloma:

  • Durie-Salmon staging system (earlier)
  • International Staging System (ISS): Three-stage system to predict survival based on:
    • β2-microglobulin
    • Albumin levels

 

Dialysis (Option A) is not the immediate next step in the management of the presented case. Dialysis is primarily used in cases of severe renal failure where conservative management measures have failed.

Dexamethasone + lenalidomide (an immunomodulatory drug) (Option B) combination is typically included in the treatment regimen for multiple myeloma, but it is not the immediate next step.

Bone marrow transplantation (Option D) is a treatment option for multiple myeloma in certain cases, particularly in younger patients or those with high-risk disease, but not the immediate next step.

questions.text: For hairy cell leukemia, which drug is considered the preferred choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cladribine

Explanation:

  • Cladribine (also known as 2-chlorodeoxyadenosine or 2-CdA) is a purine analog chemotherapy drug that has shown high efficacy in the treatment of hairy cell leukemia. It is considered the drug of choice because it achieves high response rates and durable remissions in most patients. Deoxycoformycin is also shown to have a good remission rate.

Hairy cell leukemia

Mutations

BRAF V600E

Pathogenesis

Mutation of BRAF V600E gene → Activation of the BRAF protein → MAPK/ERK signalling pathway → Uncontrolled proliferation and survival of mature B-cells (Hairy cells).

Clinical Presentation

Presents with fatigue, recurrent infections, easy bruising, and symptoms related to splenomegaly (e.g., early satiety, abdominal discomfort), pancytopenia

Peripheral Blood Findings
  • Hairy cells with round, oblong, or reniform nuclei and pale blue cytoplasm.

Bone Marrow Biopsy Findings
  • Hypocellular or fibrotic marrow with "hairy cells".
  • Fried egg appearance.

Diagnosis
  • Flow cytometry
  • Immunophenotyping
  • Genetic testing for BRAF V600E mutation

Treatment
  • Splenectomy: Often leads to prolonged remission.
  • Nucleosides (Cladribine, Deoxycoformycin): Highly effective but cause immunosuppression;
  • Interferon-α (Option D): Effective but less so than nucleosides.
  • Vemurafenib (Option B) (BRAF inhibitor): Used in chemotherapy-refractory cases; not curative but maintains response with chronic use.
  • Vemurafenib + Rituximab (Option A): Leads to more durable remissions.

Prognosis

Excellent

 

While rituximab has shown efficacy in the treatment of various B-cell lymphomas, it is not the drug of choice for hairy cell leukemia. Cladribine is the preferred treatment for HCL.

Vemurafenib is a targeted therapy drug primarily used for the treatment of certain forms of metastatic melanoma with BRAF V600E mutation.

Interferon-alpha is a type of immunotherapy that has been used in the treatment of hairy cell leukemia in the past. It is now less commonly used.

questions.text: A ten-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with fever and swelling of his hands after playing football. He gives a history of previous episodes of swelling of his hands. On imaging, his spleen was found to be shrunken. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sickle cell anaemia

Explanation: The clinical scenario of a child with fever, recurrent swelling of the hands, and a shrunken spleen is consistent with the diagnosis of sickle cell anemia.

Clinical Features of Sickle Cell Anemia:

  • Fetal hemoglobin (HbF) persists up to 6 months of life, with a residual amount (<1%) in adulthood.
  • In regions without newborn screening, affected children are typically identified after 6 months of age.
  • Sickle cell disease does not predispose to neonatal jaundice.
  • Fever:
    • Autosplenectomy, along with reduced splenic function, increases susceptibility to infections from encapsulated bacteria:
      • Pneumococci
      • Meningococci
      • H. influenzae
  • Acute abdominal pain:
    • Occurs during vaso-occlusion or distal tissue ischemia.
    • Constant, non-positional abdominal pain, not aggravated by food, was located in the left upper quadrant and epigastric area.
    • Misdiagnosed as acute pancreatitis or splenic abscess.
  • Bone pain:
    • Sickled cells can obstruct blood flow in blood vessels supplying the bones, leading to inadequate oxygen delivery.
    • Lack of oxygen to bone tissue can cause cell death, leading to a complication called avascular necrosis (AVN).
    • IOC for avascular necrosis: MRI
  • Dactylitis/Hand and foot syndrome:
    • Refers to painful, symmetric swelling of the hands and feet in children with sickle cell disease.
    • It occurs due to infarction of the metacarpals, metatarsals, and phalanges caused by sickled erythrocytes blocking blood vessels.
    • Swelling is followed by hyperemia and subperiosteal new bone formation, visible on radiographs 10-14 days after the swelling subsides.

 

Malaria (Option B): While malaria can cause splenomegaly (enlarged spleen) due to the sequestration of parasitized red blood cells, it does not typically lead to splenic atrophy (shrunken spleen). Additionally, recurrent hand swelling is not a characteristic symptom of malaria.

Pancreatitis (Option C) refers to inflammation of the pancreas, typically presenting with severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. It does not cause symptoms such as fever, hand swelling, or splenic atrophy, which are present in this patient.

Measles (Option D) is a viral infection primarily affecting the respiratory system, with characteristic symptoms such as cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and a maculopapular rash. It does not cause splenic atrophy or recurrent hand swelling, making it unlikely in this case.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Renal failure

 

Explanation:

  • Renal failure, while it can occur as a consequence of microvascular injury in TTP, is not a defining feature of the disease.
  • Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP) is a rare hematological disorder characterized by:
    • Thrombocytopenia (Option A)
    • Thrombosis (Option B)
    • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (Option C)

 

TTP vs HUS

 

Feature

Hemolytic-Uremic Syndrome (HUS)

Etiology

Deficiency or antibodies to ADAMTS13 leading to platelet aggregation

E. coli O157:H7 or shigella

Features

Pentad

1. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA)

2. Thrombocytopenia (severe)

3. Renal failure,

4. Neurologic findings

5. Fever

Triad

1. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA)

2. Thrombocytopenia

3. Renal failure

Age Group
  • More common in adults
  • More common in children

Association
  • Often women, especially those with HIV or during pregnancy
  • Preceded by diarrhea, especially hemorrhagic diarrhea

Renal Failure
  • Not a predominant feature
  • Renal failure is a hallmark, especially in children

ADAMTS13 Activity
  • <10% ADAMTS13 activity is diagnostic
  • ADAMTS13 activity is normal, except in rare cases (Atypical HUS)

Common Precipitating Factors
  • Idiopathic
  • Infections (HIV)
  • Medications (Ticlopidine, Cyclosporine)
  • Pregnancy
  • Often follows GI infections
  • Atypical HUS has genetic/ complement involvement

Treatment
  • Plasma exchange (mainstay)
  • Glucocorticoids
  • Supportive care
  • Dialysis (in severe cases)

Relapse Rate
  • 25-45% relapse
  • Relapses can occur, but less frequent than TTP

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with a history of recurrent headaches presented for further evaluation. On further workup, haemoglobin and total WBC count were normal, while an elevated platelet count was seen. Bone marrow aspiration showed increased megakaryocytes and a JAK2 mutation. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Essential thrombocytosis

Explanation:

  • The high platelet count and JAK 2 mutation with increased megakaryocytes in the bone marrow aspiration point to the diagnosis of essential thrombocythemia.

Essential Thrombocythemia (ET)

  • This is a type of myeloproliferative neoplasm.

Aetiology:

  • Caused by mutations in JAK2, CALR, or MPL genes, known as "driver mutations."
  • Other mutations associated: SH2B3, TP53, IDH2, 20q-, etc.

Pathophysiology:

  • JAK2V617F mutation (valine to phenylalanine) activates hematopoietic cytokine receptors, leading to myeloproliferation.
  • CALR mutations result in abnormal protein, affecting cellular proliferation and differentiation.
  • MPL mutations affect thrombopoietin receptor function, increasing thrombocytosis risk.
  • Extreme thrombocytosis (>1 million platelets) can lead to bleeding episodes due to acquired von Willebrand disease.

Symptoms & Risks:

  • Characterized by high platelet count and megakaryocytic hyperplasia in bone marrow.
  • Risks include thrombosis, haemorrhage, and potential progression to myelofibrosis or leukemic transformation.

Diagnosis:

questions.text: A child with progressive pallor and bone has an elevated HbS based on the HPLC report. Which is the best treatment to manage hemolysis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Voxelotor:

Explanation:

  • HPLC (High-Performance Liquid Chromatography) showing elevated HbS indicates Sickle Cell Disease (SCD). SCD is due to a mutation in β-globin gene → HbS polymerizes under low oxygen → sickling → chronic hemolysis + vaso-occlusive crises.
  • Voxelotor is an HbS polymerization inhibitor that increases hemoglobin’s affinity for oxygen, stabilizing the oxygenated form and reducing RBC sickling. This directly reduces hemolysis and improves anemia, making it the best treatment here for hemolysis control.

Sickle Cell Disease (SCD):

  • Pathophysiology: Point mutation (Glu → Val) in β-chain of Hb → polymerization in deoxygenated state → distorted RBCs → hemolysis + microvascular occlusion.
  • Clinical features:
    • Hemolytic anemia (pallor, jaundice, gallstones)
    • Pain crises (bone pain, chest pain, abdomen)
    • Dactylitis in children
    • Splenic infarction → functional asplenia → infection risk
  • Diagnosis: HPLC / electrophoresis (↑ HbS, ± HbF, ↓ HbA)
  • Management:
    • Hydroxyurea (↑ HbF, reduces crises)
    • Voxelotor (↓ hemolysis, ↑ Hb)
    • L-glutamine (↓ oxidative stress)
    • Crizanlizumab (P-selectin inhibitor, ↓ vaso-occlusion)
    • Supportive: vaccination, folate, transfusion if needed

Incorrect Options:

Hydroxyurea (Option A) – Increases HbF, reduces frequency of pain crises and acute chest syndrome, but has less direct effect on hemolysis than voxelotor.

Azacytidine (Option B) – DNA methyltransferase inhibitor used in myelodysplastic syndromes/AML, not for SCD.

Bortezomib (Option D) – Proteasome inhibitor used in multiple myeloma, unrelated to SCD.

questions.text: What defect is seen in Bernard Soulier syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Deficiency of GpIb receptors:

Explanation:

  • Bernard–Soulier syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive platelet disorder characterized by a defect in platelet adhesion due to deficiency or dysfunction of the platelet membrane glycoprotein Ib (GpIb) complex, which is the receptor for von Willebrand factor (vWF).
  • This defect prevents platelets from binding to exposed subendothelial vWF during vascular injury, leading to defective primary hemostasis.
  • Clinically, it presents with mucocutaneous bleeding, prolonged bleeding time, and thrombocytopenia with giant platelets on peripheral smear.

Incorrect Options:

Deficiency of GpIIb/IIIa receptor (Option A): Seen in Glanzmann thrombasthenia — causes defective platelet aggregation, not adhesion.

Deficiency of von Willebrand factor (Option C): Seen in von Willebrand disease — results in both defective platelet adhesion and secondary coagulation defect due to reduced factor VIII stability.

Deficiency of ADP receptors (Option D): Seen in rare platelet function disorders like P2Y12 receptor defects — affects aggregation via ADP pathway, not adhesion.

questions.text: A female patient presents to the AIIMS emergency department with severe fatigue. She is a known case of chronic stable angina. While collecting a blood sample, you notice the blood has a brownish hue. What is the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The underlying diagnosis in this case is methemoglobinemia.

Methemoglobinemia is a condition in which there is an increased level of methemoglobin, a form of hemoglobin that is unable to bind and transport oxygen effectively. The blood sample has a characteristic brownish hue on examination. As the patient has a known case of chronic stable angina, it is likely that she is on nitrates, and methemoglobinemia is a side effect of nitrate.

Carboxyhemoglobinemia (Option A) results from carbon monoxide poisoning, where CO binds to hemoglobin with high affinity, reducing oxygen delivery. Patients present with cherry-red skin, headache, confusion, and severe hypoxia, but blood appears bright red, not brown.

Sideroblastic anemia (Option B) is a disorder of heme synthesis, often associated with iron overload and ringed sideroblasts in the bone marrow, leading to microcytic anemia. It does not cause brown-colored blood.

Sulfhemoglobinemia (Option D) is caused by sulfur-containing drugs (e.g., sulfonamides, metoclopramide), leading to irreversible oxidation of hemoglobin and presenting with greenish/bluish blood and cyanosis, which, unlike methemoglobinemia, does not respond to methylene blue.

questions.text: What is the mutation seen in Sickle cell anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Glu → Val (6)

 

Explanation:

  • Sickle cell anemia is a genetic disorder caused by a missense mutation in the β-globin gene.
  • This mutation replaces the normal glutamic acid (Glu) at position 6 of the β-globin chain with valine (Val).

 

  • This Glu → Val substitution leads to the formation of hemoglobin S (HbS), which tends to polymerize when deoxygenated, causing the red blood cells to become sickle-shaped.
  • These sickle-shaped cells are rigid and prone to breaking, leading to anemia and other complications.

 

Pathophysiology of Sickle cell anemia

  • HbS Polymerisation:
    • A single-nucleotide polymorphism in the β-globin gene results in the substitution of valine for glutamic acid at the sixth position in the β-globin chain.
    • This mutation leads to the formation of mutated hemoglobin (HbS).
    • After deoxygenation, HbS molecules polymerize to form bundles.
    • These polymer bundles cause erythrocytes to adopt a sickle shape and also promote hemolysis of erythrocyte, releasing cell-free Hb into circulation.
  • Vaso-occlusion:
    • Sickled erythrocytes impair blood flow and aggregate with neutrophils, platelets, and endothelial cells, causing stasis.
    • Leads to ischemia-reperfusion (I-R) injury.
  • Endothelial Dysfunction:
    • Oxygenated Hb (Fe²⁺) depletes endothelial nitric oxide (NO), forming nitrate (NO₃⁻) and methemoglobin (Fe³⁺).
    • Free radicals are generated by NADPH oxidase, xanthine oxidase (XO), and uncoupled endothelial NO synthase (eNOS) contribute to endothelial damage and dysfunction.
    • Methemoglobin (Fe³⁺) breaks down, releasing cell-free heme, which is a major erythrocyte damage-associated molecular pattern (DAMP).
  • Sterile Inflammation:
    • Cell-free heme or ischemia-reperfusion injury triggers sterile inflammation by:
      • Generating reactive oxygen species (ROS).
      • Activating Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4).
      • Inducing neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs).
      • Releasing DAMPs, DNA, and other unidentified factors.
    • This activates the inflammasome pathway, releasing IL-1β.
    • Sterile inflammation enhances the adhesiveness of neutrophils, platelets, and endothelial cells.
    • This creates a cycle that promotes further vaso-occlusion.

  • Serum transaminases are raised (3): Raised transaminases (ALT, AST) are markers of liver damage, not hemolysis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding von Willebrand disease is incorrect?

choices.text: Type 2 von Willebrand disease is associated with a moderate bleeding tendency
Type 3 von Willebrand disease is associated with a complete absence of factor VIII
Type 1 von Willebrand disease presents with severe bleeding since childhood
Type 2 von Willebrand disease includes subtypes with varying defects in von Willebrand factor.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Type 1 von Willebrand disease presents with severe bleeding since childhood:

  • This statement is incorrect. Type 1 von Willebrand disease is the mildest form of the condition and is characterized by a partial deficiency of von Willebrand factor (vWF). Patients typically experience mild bleeding symptoms rather than severe ones. It often presents with mild bleeding tendencies rather than severe, and symptoms may not be apparent until later in life.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Type 2 von Willebrand disease is associated with a moderate bleeding tendency: This statement is correct. Type 2 von Willebrand disease is characterized by a qualitative defect in von Willebrand factor, which leads to a moderate bleeding tendency. This type includes several subtypes with different defects in the von Willebrand factor.

Option B - Type 3 von Willebrand disease is associated with a complete absence of factor VIII: This statement is partially correct but misleading. Type 3 von Willebrand disease is associated with a severe deficiency or absence of von Willebrand factor, not factor VIII. However, since von Willebrand factor stabilizes factor VIII, the absence of vWF can lead to very low levels of factor VIII.

Option D - Type 2 von Willebrand disease includes subtypes with varying defects in von Willebrand factor: This statement is correct. Type 2 von Willebrand disease includes several subtypes (e.g., 2A, 2B, 2M, 2N), each with different defects affecting the function of von Willebrand factor.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding myelodysplastic syndrome?

choices.text: Treatment-induced MDS is not dependent on age

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - More commonly seen in females:

  • MDS is actually more commonly seen in males than in females.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are true regarding myelodysplastic syndrome.
  • The median age of onset for MDS is around 70 years, making it primarily a disease of the elderly. It can be induced by radiation exposure, either as a part of cancer treatment or from other sources of significant radiation exposure. Treatment-induced MDS is not dependent on age.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with a history of lower back pain and painful urination. Upon investigation, he is found to have normocytic normochromic anemia and hypercalcemia. Serum protein electrophoresis reveals an M-spike in the gamma region. Which of the following tests is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis of multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bence Jones protein in urine

Explanation:

  • Clinical features of CRAB (hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, anemia, and bone lesions), along with the presence of an Gamma region M spike in serum electrophoresis, point towards the diagnosis of Multiple myeloma.

Investigations of Multiple myeloma:

  • Hematological Analysis:
    • It may reveal anemia; ESR is usually elevated.
    • Rare cases of plasma cell leukemia with high plasma cell counts >2000 plasma cells/μL.
    • Serum calcium and urea nitrogen may be elevated.
    • Serum alkaline phosphatase is usually normal.
    • Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation
  • A/G ratio: Decreased
    • Increased level of β2 microglobulin.
    • Decreased albumin
  • Renal function test: Increased serum creatinine and uric acid.
  • Imaging:
    • Chest and bone radiographs: Lytic lesions/diffuse osteopenia
    • MRI: Extent of bone marrow infiltration and cord or root compression in patients with pain syndrome
    • PET/CT: Assess bone damage, extramedullary sites of the disease
  • Anion gap: (Na+ + K+) – (Cl- + HCO3-): Decreased
  • Serum or urine electrophoresis: M spike
  • Serum light chain assay: Increased
  • Immunofixation: Detects subtypes of light chain.
  • 24-hour urine specimen: Bence Jones protein (serum-free light chains) excretion
  • Fat pad biopsy: To detect amyloid deposits
  • Flow cytometry: CD 138+ (bone marrow plasma cells)
  • FISH:
    • Done to detect chromosomal abnormalities
    • Chromosome 17 deletion and translocation leads to poor prognosis.
  • Bone marrow biopsy: Plasmacytosis >10%

 

Liver function test (Option A): While liver function tests may be abnormal in some patients with multiple myeloma, they are not specific or diagnostic for the condition. LFTs are more useful in assessing liver involvement or complications.

Urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio (Option C): This test assesses kidney function and proteinuria but is not specific for multiple myeloma. While renal function may be affected in myeloma, UACR doesn't detect the characteristic Bence Jones proteins.

Heat and acetic acid test (Option D): This is an outdated test that is not used in modern diagnosis of multiple myeloma. Current diagnostic methods are more sensitive and specific.

questions.text: A young woman presents with recurrent headaches, easy bruising, and episodes of visual blurring. Her platelet count is elevated, while her red blood cell (RBC) and white blood cell (WBC) counts are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Essential Thrombocytosis

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate Essential Thrombocytosis, a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by an isolated elevation in platelet count. The patient presents with classic symptoms including headaches, easy bruising, and visual disturbances, along with the key diagnostic finding of elevated platelets with normal RBC and WBC counts.
  • This condition results from abnormal proliferation of megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, leading to excessive platelet production.

 

Essential Thrombocytosis

Definition
  • Clonal myeloproliferative disorder
  • Characterized by increased platelet production
  • Abnormal megakaryocyte proliferation

Genetics
  • JAK2 V617F mutation (50-60% of cases)
  • CALR mutations (type 1 and 2)
  • MPL mutations

Lab Findings
  • Platelet count >450,000/μL
  • Increased bone marrow megakaryocytes
  • Normal RBC and WBC Count

Clinical Features
  • Often asymptomatic
  • Thrombotic events (arterial > venous)
  • Erythromelalgia
  • Ocular migraines & visual disturbances
  • TIAs
  • Spontaneous bleeding & easy bruising

Diagnostic Criteria
  • Platelet count >450,000/μL
  • Bone marrow showing megakaryocyte proliferation
  • Not meeting WHO criteria for other myeloid neoplasms
  • Presence of JAK2, CALR, or MPL mutation

Complications
  • Thrombosis (major cause of morbidity)
  • Hemorrhage (especially with counts >1 million/μL)
  • Progression to myelofibrosis
  • Small risk of leukemic transformation

Treatment
  • Low-dose aspirin for thrombosis prevention
  • Hydroxyurea for high-risk patients
  • Anagrelide for cytoreduction
  • Plateletpheresis for severe cases

 

Polycythemia Vera (Option B) presents with elevated levels of all three blood cell lines—RBCs, WBCs, and platelets. The normal RBC count in this case makes this diagnosis unlikely. Patients typically present with ruddy complexion, pruritus, and thrombotic complications.

Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (Option C) typically shows elevation in granulocytes and often an increase in platelets as well. The presence of normal WBC count makes CML an unlikely diagnosis, as it characteristically presents with marked leukocytosis.

Acute Myeloid Leukemia (Option D) typically presents with abnormal levels of blood cells and can show varying counts of WBCs, RBCs, and platelets. The normal blood counts except for platelets make AML less likely, as it usually presents with cytopenias and blast cells in the peripheral blood.

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of fatigue, pallor, and weakness. Laboratory tests reveal a low hemoglobin (Hb) level, but the reticulocyte count is normal. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pure Red Cell Aplasia

Explanation:

  • Pure Red Cell Aplasia is characterized by a selective deficiency in red blood cell production while other blood cell lines remain normal. The key diagnostic features in this case are the combination of low hemoglobin with a normal reticulocyte count, indicating an inadequate bone marrow response specific to the erythroid lineage. This selective depression of red blood cell production, with preservation of white blood cells and platelets, is the hallmark of PRCA.

 

Pure Red Cell Aplasia

Definition

A condition characterized by anemia, reticulocytopenia, and absent or rare erythroid precursor cells in bone marrow with normal white cell and platelet production

Classification

Congenital:

  • Diamond-Blackfan anemia
  • Diagnosed at birth or early childhood

Acquired:

  • Thymoma
  • MDS (5s- syndrome)
  • Cancer
  • Autoimmune conditions
  • Viral infections (especially B19 parvovirus)

Clinical Associations
  • Thymoma (most frequent)
  • Lymphoid malignancies
  • Autoimmune disorders
  • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Pregnancy

Pathophysiology
  • T-cell mediated immune response
  • Antibodies to erythropoietin
  • Neutralizing antibodies to B19 parvovirus
  • Direct chemical toxicity or immune destruction

Treatment

General Approach:

  • Identify and treat underlying cause
  • Regular monitoring of hemoglobin levels
  • Supportive care with transfusions

Specific Treatments:

  • Immunosuppression (corticosteroids, cyclosporine, ATG, azathioprine)
  • Intravenous immunoglobulin for B19 parvovirus infection
  • Thymectomy if thymoma present
  • Iron chelation as needed

 

Aplastic Anemia (Option A) presents with pancytopenia, affecting all blood cell lines (red cells, white cells, and platelets) due to bone marrow failure. The normal reticulocyte count in this case does not support aplastic anemia, which would show decreased counts across all cell lines.

Iron Deficiency Anemia (Option C) typically shows microcytic, hypochromic red blood cells with an elevated reticulocyte count as the bone marrow attempts to compensate for the iron deficiency. The normal reticulocyte count in this scenario makes iron deficiency less likely.

Hemolytic Anemia (Option D) is characterized by increased destruction of red blood cells, leading to an elevated reticulocyte count as the bone marrow responds to the increased demand. The normal reticulocyte count in this case does not support ongoing hemolysis.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a complication of blood transfusion in a 25-year-old mother who developed acute postpartum haemorrhage (PPH), hypovolemic shock, and underwent major blood transfusion after delivering a baby boy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Hypokalemia

  • Hypokalemia is not seen with blood transfusions. Instead, hyperkalemia occurs due to leakage of potassium from red blood cells in stored blood.

Complications of Massive Blood Transfusion

Complication

Cause

Effect

Prevention/ Management

Hypothermia (Option C)

Transfusion of cold blood (stored at 4°C).

Body temperature drops, leading to impaired clotting mechanisms (coagulopathy), and worsening bleeding.
  • Warm blood products before transfusion
  • Use external warming methods (e.g., warming blankets).

Coagulopathy

Dilution of clotting factors and platelets due to transfusion; consumption of clotting factors by ongoing haemorrhage.

Impaired blood clotting, prolonged bleeding time, increased risk of continued bleeding.
  • Administer fresh frozen plasma (FFP), platelets, and cryoprecipitate.
  • For massive BT, blood products should be administered in a 1:1:1 ratio.
  • Monitor clotting factors (e.g., PT, aPTT).

Citrate Toxicity

Large volumes of transfused blood contain citrate, which binds to calcium.

Hypocalcemia (Option A), leads to muscle cramps, seizures, and cardiac arrhythmias.

Administer calcium gluconate or calcium chloride prophylactically.

Hyperkalemia (Option D)

Potassium leaks from stored red blood cells into plasma during storage.

Elevated potassium levels (hyperkalemia) can cause cardiac arrhythmias, potentially leading to cardiac arrest.
  • Monitor potassium levels.
  • Administer calcium to stabilize the myocardium.
  • Insulin with glucose to shift potassium intracellularly if needed.

Metabolic Alkalosis

Rapid metabolism of citrate into bicarbonate.

Increased pH (alkalosis) can lead to muscle twitching, irritability, and impaired oxygen release from haemoglobin.
  • Monitor arterial blood gases (ABG)
  • Adjust transfusion speed and, if necessary, reduce bicarbonate levels.

Metabolic Acidosis

Inadequate tissue perfusion leads to lactic acid accumulation.

Lowered blood pH (acidosis) leads to confusion, fatigue, rapid breathing, and worsened cardiovascular function.
  • Correct underlying cause (e.g., improve perfusion).
  • Administer sodium bicarbonate in severe cases of acidosis.

Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI)

Antibodies in transfused blood activate the recipient's immune response, causing inflammation and fluid buildup in the lungs.

Non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema, presenting as acute respiratory distress with hypoxia within 6 hours of transfusion.
  • Immediate cessation of transfusion.
  • Oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation if necessary.

Transfusion Associated Circulatory Overload (TACO)

The volume of transfused blood exceeds the patient’s capacity to manage, leading to fluid overload.

Pulmonary oedema, shortness of breath, hypertension, and signs of heart failure.
  • Administer diuretics (e.g., furosemide).
  • Slow the rate of transfusion.

Iron Overload

Repeated transfusions lead to excessive accumulation of iron.

Iron deposits in organs (e.g., liver, heart, pancreas), lead to organ damage and failure over time.

Administer iron chelators (e.g., deferoxamine, deferasirox).

Hemolytic Reactions

ABO or Rh incompatibility.

Rapid destruction of red blood cells (hemolysis), causes fever, chills, hemoglobinuria, and potentially acute renal failure or shock.
  • Immediate cessation of transfusion.
  • Supportive care with IV fluids.

Allergic Reactions

Reaction to proteins in transfused blood products.

Symptoms range from mild itching, rash, or hives to severe anaphylaxis (airway constriction, low blood pressure, shock).
  • Administer antihistamines for mild reactions.
  • Corticosteroids and epinephrine for severe reactions like anaphylaxis.

Bacterial Contamination

Blood products are contaminated during collection or storage.

Sepsis is characterized by fever, chills, low blood pressure, and possibly septic shock.
  • Immediate cessation of transfusion.
  • Administer broad-spectrum antibiotics.

questions.text: Elective splenectomy is preferred in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C- Hereditary spherocytosis

  • Hereditary spherocytosis is an inherited disorder characterized by abnormal red blood cells that are spherical in shape instead of the normal biconcave disc shape. Elective splenectomy is the primary treatment for Hereditary spherocytosis.
  • In HS, splenectomy is particularly effective because the spleen is the primary site of spherocyte destruction. The timing of splenectomy varies with disease severity: severe HS requires elective splenectomy at 4-6 years of age, moderate HS can be delayed until puberty, while mild cases may be managed with folic acid supplementation alone.

Management of Hereditary Spherocytosis (HS)

Splenectomy as Primary Treatment
  • Splenectomy significantly improves anemia by prolonging red cell survival, reducing the need for transfusions, and preventing iron overload and related organ damage.
  • Post splenectomy: Spherocytosis and altered osmotic fragility persist, but reticulocyte counts and erythrocyte lifespan normalize.

Blood Film Changes Post-Splenectomy
  • Features like Howell-Jolly bodies, acanthocytes, target cells, cabot ring and Pappenheimer bodies appear after splenectomy.

 

Indications for Splenectomy
  • Recommended for patients with severe, transfusion-dependent anemia, growth failure, skeletal changes, leg ulcers, or extramedullary hematopoietic tumors.

Timing of Splenectomy:

  • Should be delayed until age 5–9 if possible or at least age 3, to reduce the risk of post-splenectomy sepsis while balancing the increased risk of gallstones in older children.

Laparoscopic Splenectomy
  • Preferred method, with benefits like less discomfort, quicker recovery, and shorter hospital stays. Combined laparoscopic splenectomy and cholecystectomy is an option for patients with symptomatic gallstones.

Partial Splenectomy
  • Used in infants or young children to alleviate anemia while preserving some splenic immune function. It reduces transfusion needs but may eventually require total splenectomy in about half of patients.

Pre- and Post-Splenectomy Care

 

  • Vaccination: Patients should receive vaccines against pneumococcus, Haemophilus influenzae type B, and meningococcus before surgery.
  • Antibiotic Prophylaxis: Use of prophylactic antibiotics post-splenectomy is controversial but recommended by some for at least 5 years or even lifelong.
  • Folic Acid: Continued supplementation (1 mg/day) is recommended to prevent folate deficiency.

G6PD deficiency (Option A): In G6PD deficiency, splenectomy may actually worsen the anemia because the spleen filters and removes damaged red blood cells from the circulation. The primary management involves avoiding oxidative stressors and managing acute hemolytic episodes.

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (Option B): In PNH, there is an abnormality in the complement system, and stem cell transplant is the best curative treatment. Splenectomy is not indicated as the hemolysis is complement-mediated and occurs throughout the circulation.

Hairy cell leukemia (Option D): In hairy cell leukemia, chemotherapy is the standard treatment. Splenectomy may be considered only in cases with massively enlarged spleen or if there is resistance to other treatments, but it is not the preferred initial treatment option.

questions.text: Which test is utilized for the diagnosis of DIC among the following options?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Dimer assay:

  • D-dimer assay is a blood test used to detect the presence of D-dimer, a fibrin degradation product that is elevated in conditions associated with fibrin formation and breakdown, such as DIC.
  • Elevated D-dimer levels indicate the activation of the clotting system and can support the diagnosis of DIC.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Fibrin degradation products is incorrect because while the presence of fibrin degradation products is a characteristic feature of DIC, the specific test used for their detection is the D-dimer assay.

Option B - Activated partial thromboplastin time is incorrect because activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) is a coagulation test that measures the intrinsic pathway of coagulation and is not specific to the diagnosis of DIC.

Option C - Prothrombin time is incorrect because prothrombin time (PT) is a coagulation test that measures the extrinsic pathway of coagulation and is not specific to the diagnosis of DIC.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents with fatigue, pallor, weight loss, and heaviness in the left hypochondrium, for the past 2 months. Abdominal palpation reveals splenomegaly. His hemogram and peripheral smear results are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb-10 gm/dl
WBC count – 1,65,000/cu.mm 
(leukocytosis)
Platelet count – 3 lakhs/mm3
Peripheral smear: 
Metamyelocytes – 15%
Promyeloblasts – 30%
Myeloblasts – 45%
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis for the patient in this scenario is chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).
  • The patient has leukocytosis with a very high white blood cell count (1,65,000/cu.mm), which is a hallmark of CML. Additionally, the peripheral smear shows an increase in myeloblasts, promyelocytes, and metamyelocytes, which are immature forms of white blood cells commonly seen in CML.

Incorrect choices:

  • Option A: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is a type of leukemia that typically presents with lymphocytosis, or an increase in lymphocytes, rather than leukocytosis. The peripheral smear would also show an increase in lymphocytes rather than myeloid cells.
  • Option C: In Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the peripheral smear would show a predominance of lymphoblasts rather than myeloblasts.
  • Option D: In Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a type of leukemia that presents with symptoms such as fatigue, fever, and easy bruising or bleeding. AML typically presents with more acute symptoms and a shorter disease course compared to CML.

questions.text:
A patient with thalassemia has a history of multiple blood transfusions, iron overload, and cardiac arrhythmia. She has now come for blood transfusion and during the process,
complains of backache and looks very anxious. What would you do next?

choices.text: Continue the transfusion but do an ECG
Stop the transfusion. Wait for patient to become normal and then start it again
Do clerical check and get ECG

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Stop the blood transfusion:

  • In a patient with thalassemia who has a history of multiple blood transfusions, iron overload, and cardiac arrhythmia, the presenting symptoms of backache and anxiety during a blood transfusion raise concerns for a transfusion reaction, specifically an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction.
  • In this scenario, the appropriate course of action is to stop the blood transfusion immediately to prevent further complications. Once the transfusion is stopped, the patient should be closely monitored for any signs of worsening symptoms, and supportive measures should be initiated as necessary.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Continue the transfusion but do an ECG: Continuing the transfusion without addressing the potential transfusion reaction can lead to further complications and risks the patient's safety.

Option C - Stop the transfusion, wait for the patient to become normal, and then start it again: This approach is not recommended because a suspected transfusion reaction requires prompt action. Stopping the transfusion is the first step to prevent the reaction from worsening and to ensure the patient's safety.

Option D - Do clerical check and get ECG: While a clerical check and ECG may be relevant in certain situations, such as ensuring the correct blood product is being transfused or assessing for potential cardiac complications.

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed bleeding manifestation in individuals with severe hemophilia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Recurrent hemarthrosis:

  • In severe hemophilia, which is characterized by a deficiency of clotting factor VIII (hemophilia A) or clotting factor IX (hemophilia B), the most common bleeding manifestation is recurrent hemarthrosis.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A - Recurrent hematomas: While hematomas can occur in individuals with severe hemophilia, they are not as common as recurrent hemarthrosis.

Option C - Hematuria: Hematuria, which is the presence of blood in the urine, can occur in hemophilia, but it is not the most common bleeding manifestation.

Option D - Intracranial hemorrhage: Intracranial hemorrhage, which refers to bleeding within the skull or brain, is a severe complication of hemophilia but is relatively rare.

questions.text: What is incorrect regarding Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Increased fibrinogen:

  • Increased fibrinogen is wrong about DIC (Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation).
  • DIC is characterized by activation of coagulation system
  • In DIC, fibrinogen levels decrease as it's consumed in clot formation, not increased, because it's used up in the excessive clotting process.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increased schistocytes: In DIC, the presence of schistocytes is a characteristic finding due to the formation of microvascular clots and the subsequent shearing of red blood cells.

Option B - Increased PT:In DIC, there is activation of the coagulation system, leading to consumption of clotting factors. This consumption results in prolongation of PT, indicating impaired clotting function.

Option D - Increased FDPs: In DIC, there is increased activation of the fibrinolytic system, leading to increased levels of FDPs. Elevated levels of FDPs are often observed in DIC and can be used as a diagnostic marker.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with the diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia was treated medically. She developed fever and tachypnea and a chest X-ray showed pulmonary infiltrates. What drug should she be given next?

These symptoms and findings suggest the development of a potentially serious complication called acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) associated with APL.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cytarabine: Cytarabine is a chemotherapy drug commonly used in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia (AML), including certain subtypes of APL.

Option C - Doxorubicin: Doxorubicin is a chemotherapy drug commonly used in the treatment of various cancers, including APL.

Option D - Methotrexate: Methotrexate is a chemotherapy drug used in the treatment of various malignancies, including certain types of leukemia.

questions.text: Adhesion of platelets is the main function of von-willebrand factor. Which of the following is true for von-willebrand disease?

Correct Option C - Normal prothrombin time:

  • Prothrombin time is not affected in von-willebrand disease as von-willebrand factor affects only the intrinsic factor.

Incorrect options:

Option D - "Normal bleeding time": Since von Willebrand factor plays a crucial role in platelet adhesion, patients with VWD may have an increased bleeding time due to impaired platelet function. Therefore, option D is incorrect.

questions.text: What is the treatment for neutropenia following chemotherapy?

questions.text: What is the most probable condition of a 10-year-old boy complaining of recurrent episodes of intense pain in his fingers and toes that spontaneously resolve over the course of the last year?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sickle cell anemia:

  • Sickle cell anemia is a genetic blood disorder characterized by the presence of abnormal hemoglobin, known as hemoglobin S.
  • In sickle cell anemia, the abnormal red blood cells can become stiff and sticky, leading to blockages in the blood vessels.
  • These blockages can cause episodes of pain called vaso-occlusive crises of sickle cell crises. These crises can occur in various parts of the body, including the bones, joints, and organs.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Alpha-thalassemia: Alpha-thalassemia is a genetic disorder characterized by reduced or absent production of alpha-globin chains. It can lead to anemia, but it typically does not cause episodes of pain or resolve on its own.

Option B - Beta-thalassemia: Beta-thalassemia is a genetic disorder characterized by reduced or absent production of beta-globin chains. Similar to alpha-thalassemia, it can cause anemia but does not typically present with episodes of pain that resolve spontaneously.

Option D - Von Willebrand disease type 1: Von Willebrand disease is a bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor, a protein involved in blood clotting.

questions.text: Which statement is accurate regarding paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)?

Correct Option C - Deficiency of CD55 and CD59:

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia with a blood type O negative presents to the transplant clinic to discuss proceeding with an allogeneic stem cell transplant. Which of the following would be an optimal donor?

questions.text: Which of the following factors hinder the absorption of iron?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Phytates: 

  • Phytates are naturally occurring compounds found in certain plant foods such as whole grains, legumes, and nuts. They have the ability to bind to iron and form insoluble complexes, which reduces the absorption of iron in the digestive tract. This can lead to decreased iron availability for the body.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Vitamin C: Vitamin C, also known as ascorbic acid, actually enhances iron absorption. It helps in the conversion of non-heme iron (the form of iron found in plant-based foods) to a more absorbable form.

Option C - Oxalate: Oxalate, found in certain foods like spinach, rhubarb, and beet greens, can affect calcium absorption, but they do not directly inhibit iron absorption.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the diagnosis of accelerated phase of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)?

  • This statement is true. Blast concentration in PBS should be greater than 15% is one of the diagnostic criteria for accelerated phase of CML.

questions.text: What would be the most appropriate course of action for managing a patient presenting with fatigue, a haemoglobin level below 9 g/dl, and sickle-shaped red blood cells on peripheral smear examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Blood transfusion

 

Explanation:

 

The most appropriate course of action for managing a patient presenting with fatigue, a hemoglobin level below 9 g/dL, and sickle-shaped red blood cells on peripheral smear examination is blood transfusion.

In patients with sickle cell disease (SCD), a hemoglobin (Hb) level below 9 g/dL accompanied by symptoms such as fatigue indicates significant anemia. Blood transfusion is the primary treatment to increase the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood, alleviate symptoms, and prevent complications associated with severe anemia.

According to the 2014 evidence-based report by expert panel members, transfusion therapy is recommended in SCD patients with symptomatic anemia to improve oxygen delivery and reduce the risk of stroke and other complications.

Wait and watch (Option D): Delaying treatment in symptomatic anemia can lead to worsening hypoxia and increased risk of complications.
